cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course that explores the development, physiology and continually changing function of the nervous system as it relates to certain types of human behaviour. Critical analysis of scientific evidence is used to enrich learning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Neuroscience

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Tutorials start in the first week of term. Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online synchronously via webinar. The course instructor will provide details.

Student attendance at all lectures and tutorials is strongly encouraged. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view  asynchronously.

courses.name: Introduction to Fundamental Genetics and its Applications

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Gene Therapy, Gene Editing, Epigenetic Manipulations & Regenerative Medicine

sections.name: LEC9101
sections.subTitle: Gene Therapy, Gene Editing, Epigenetic Manipulations & Regenerative Medicine

cmCourseInfo.description: The course provides a comprehensive introduction to a variety of therapeutic approaches including gene therapy, CRISPR-based gene editing, epigenetic manipulations & regenerative medicine. This course consists of three parts: tools and techniques of gene & genome manipulations; medical, environmental and agricultural biotechnology applications; and ethical, legal and social aspects of modern biotechnology as it pertains to human health and wellbeing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Fundamental Genetics and its Applications

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed. Lecture recordings will be available for students to view asynchronously. 
Tutorial quizzes as well as timed online exams are delivered per the meeting schedule, or during the final exam assessment period. Students need access to Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course in Health and Disease using an interdisciplinary approach that integrates bacteriology and virology with other aspects of human biology, including chronic disease and neoplasia. An exploration of the key concepts and approaches that are necessary for understanding the dynamic nexus of human health and disease. (Lab Fees: $40)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health and Disease

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online asynchronous; learning is self-paced.  Tutorials will be delivered synchronously online using Blackboard Collaborate as per the meeting schedule. Students need Blackboard Collaborate as part of Quercus and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course covering the theories, operational components and strategies of implementing health care in resource-poor settings. Topics may include education, control of vector-borne diseases, essential drug provision, maternal and child health, nutrition, incorporation of alternative and complementary technologies, community participation and deployment of health service providers
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Global Health

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

There will not be tutorials every week; on weeks that there is no tutorial, the lecture will be three hours, on weeks where there is tutorial, lecture is two hours. Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Tutorials and exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the biological, health, environmental, and sociopolitical issues that influence human health and well-being. Topics include genetic variation within and across human populations, biological variation related to the environment, determinants of health and disease, and human behaviour and development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Human Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Tutorials and exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to classical and modern methods of genetic analysis. Topics include Mendelian genetics, the genetics of human population and disease, genomics, and applications of genetics to human society.
cmCourseInfo.title: General & Human Genetics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on September 10, 2020 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Lecture recordings consisting of voiced-over PowerPoint presentations will also be posted on Quercus.  Tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.  Exams and tutorial quizzes will be synchronous (live) and delivered online per the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: This neuroscience course focuses on higher brain functions and the mechanisms underlying human and animal behaviours. Topics may include the emerging role of the gut microbiome's impact on behaviour, pathogens that alter neuronal development and the biological basis of mindfulness and placebos. In addition, the impact that exercise and sleep play in modulating these behaviours are examined. Common experimental techniques used in neuroscience research such as brain imaging and cellular genetics are emphasized.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurobiology of Behaviour

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery HyFlex model:

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Students need Blackboard Collaborate Ultra (included as part of Quercus) and the ability to use MS Teams for communications.

cmCourseInfo.description: Students gain an appreciation for how science, government and society drive the development of biotechnology products. Topics include stem cells and regenerative medicine, diagnostics, cancer therapy, biotechnology in the developing world, antibiotic alternatives, and patents.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biotechnology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and tutorials as well as timed online exams are delivered per the meeting schedule, or during the final exam assessment period. Students need access to Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory and lecture course studying the structure of the cell, various tissues and organ systems. Emphasis is on functional morphology and the adaptive response (including the inflammatory reaction) by comparing histological sections of normal tissues and organs with common diseases including neoplasia, respiratory, and liver disease. (Lab Materials Fee: $27)
cmCourseInfo.title: Vertebrate Histology and Histopathology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for practicums (PRA) will close on September 10, 2020 at 4 PM. To make changes to your PRA sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online asynchronous, learning is self-paced.  Laboratory tutorials will be delivered synchronously online using Blackboard Collaborate as per the meeting schedule. Students need Blackboard Collaborate as part of Quercus and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: A multidisciplinary emphasis on the economic, historical, social and cultural determinants of health and human rights, and how structural violence prevents progress towards human rights. Case studies reflecting global aspects of health and human rights form a framework for approaching these issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Health and Human Rights
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete, a HST200-level course/ HMB202H1/HMB203H1/HMB204H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=3 Society and Its Institutions

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded per the meeting schedule (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Students are encouraged to participate synchronously. The required class presentations will use Bb Collaborate per the meeting schedule and will be live-streamed synchronously.

Group work required by the students can be organized using the tools in the Quercus space for this course. Students can self-organize additional methods of coordination group work. However, the class presentations that are the result of this work will be need to be adapted to the Bb Collaborate platform for presentations.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advancing technology increases our ability to intervene in the course of natural events involving human health and well being. Questions arise as whether we ought to and who will benefit or be harmed. This course considers the far-reaching bioethical implications of emerging bio-technology. Topics to be explored include-but are not limited to- ethical considerations in emerging reproductive technologies, genetic alteration/genetic enhancement. Use of life support technologies, synthetic life, life extension.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethical Considerations in Emerging Technology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery HyFlex model:

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Students are encouraged to participate live. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: A laboratory course based on current research techniques for students in the Neuroscience program. Lab topics may include human brain imaging and disorders, electrophysiology, cell culture, and changes in gene expression during neuronal development. Labs start in the first week of term. (Lab Materials Fee: $60)
cmCourseInfo.title: Laboratory in Neuroscience
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete, HMB200H1/PSY290H1, HMB265H1/BIO260H1, BIO230H1/ BIO255H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students are advised that labs start in the very first week of term. Please note that enrollment for practicums (PRA) will close on September 10, 2020 at 4 PM. To make changes to your PRA sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Online Synchronous

Online-only lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).  Students are strongly encouraged to participate synchronously (live steam) when possible. Online-only tutorials will be delivered online during designated times and led by a Teaching Assistant. Quizzes and participation marks will be assessed during lab times. Students need access to Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: A laboratory course based on current research techniques and topics which may include basic microbiology, molecular biology and animal cell culture techniques, immunocytochemistry, changes in gene expression, and histological techniques. Labs start in the first week of term. (Lab Materials Fee: $70)
cmCourseInfo.title: Laboratory in Health and Disease

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students are advised that labs start in the very first week of term. Please note that enrollment for practicums (PRA) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your PRA sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures:  Lectures will be delivered live (synchronously) at the scheduled class time. Recordings of lectures will be available to students to view asynchronously.

Labs:  Virtual lab facilitation sessions will be delivered live (synchronously) at the scheduled chosen lab time. Recordings of these lab facilitation sessions will be available to students to view asynchronously. Recordings of lab experiments/protocols will be posted weekly and available for asynchronous viewing.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a rigorous, introductory course that addresses the structure of the vertebrate central nervous system with an emphasis on functional human neuroanatomy. It is designed for students who intend to continue with studies in the Neurosciences and related areas.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neuroanatomy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete, PSL300H1, HMB200H1/PSY290H1, BIO230H1/ BIO255H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for practicums (PRA) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your PRA sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous. These will be recorded.
Labs will be delivered as online synchronous (not recorded).
Assessments will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule or during a final assessment period.
Microphone and Video. These functions are required for this course.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: The overall theme of this course is human genetics in disease. Topics include the molecular basis of human disease, using model organisms to identify disease-related genes, and genetic counseling. Expert guest lectures from clinical and basic sciences as well as small group work in tutorials build in-depth understanding.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Genetics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Tutorials and exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore the scientific basis and interdisciplinary healthcare practices of several diseases (diseases vary by year). Discuss current issues related to the biology and the impact of these diseases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Health & Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete,  HMB202H1/ HMB203H1/ HMB204H1, BIO230H1/BIO255H1, PSL300H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Tutorials and exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Globalization of health problems impacts biomedical research. Current global health research advances are explored and global health research skills are developed. Both provide background preparation for global health research, particularly in international settings.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Health Research

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Tutorials and exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 25, 2020: Time Change

cmCourseInfo.description: This course engages students in the fundamental science of epidemiology applied to health and disease. After an introduction to various measures of health and disease, the scientific methods used to investigate, analyze, prevent and control health problems will be illustrated using social, biomedical and public health examples
cmCourseInfo.title: Epidemiology of Health & Disease

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that enrollment for tutorials (TUT) will close on January 11, 2021 at 4 PM. To make changes to your TUT sections after this date, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are mostly asynchronous, but some will be live according to the lecture schedule and also recorded for asynchronous viewing. Tutorials and exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Genetic basis of both the normal and abnormal development of the nervous system and its function. Topics include the regulation of neural gene expression, the role of epigenetics on neuron function, genome wide association studies and disorders of brain and behaviour, optogenetic and pharmacogenetic techniques to probe neural circuit function. Tutorials emphasize critical analysis of primary research.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurogenomics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery HyFlex model:

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and tutorials and timed online exams are delivered per the meeting schedule, or during the final exam assessment period. Students need access to Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (or MS teams).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces life science students to biomedical advances and technologies in medicine, including drug patents, medical device implants, diagnostic and medical device software. Limitations of patent protection in commercializing medical products, and limitations to scalability may also be discussed. Specific topics vary from year to year and will be based on the course instructor's area(s) of expertise.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biomedical Advances & Technologies

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: The bridge between basic scientific research and clinical practice integrates fundamental knowledge about molecular/cellular mechanisms and clinical disorders to increase the potential for new medical treatments, therapies and interventions as well as understanding of disease processes. Specific topics vary from year to year and will be based on the instructor's area(s) of expertise.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Translational Medicine
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, BCH210H1, BIO230H1/BIO255H1, HMB302H1/HMB321H1/HMB322H1/BCH311H1/CSB349H1/MGY311Y1/PSL350H1, and HMB202H1/HMB203H1/HMB204H1

Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery HyFlex model:

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Student presentations and/or exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Since research involving human subjects lays the foundation for innovation in modern health care, this course examines health care ethics along a continuum from bench to bedside. Ethical issues are discussed in the context of specific cases involving human research, as well as contemporary clinical practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Care Ethics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete,  A HMB300-level course, HMB306H1/ PHL281H1/ other ethics course with prior approval from the unit

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar course focuses on recent research into the neurobiology underlying human behaviour. A variety of normal and abnormal human behaviours are studied which may include: voluntary action; moral cognition; hedonism; aggression; mental health; addiction; the impact of the gut microbiome on brain development and health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Neurobiology of Behaviour

cmCourseInfo.description: Current research covering the breadth of neuroscience is showcased by members of the Collaborative Program in Neuroscience. Topics vary yearly, but cover the spectrum from molecular through genetic, cellular, developmental, systems, behavioural and modelling. As well, approaches to studying neurodegenerative diseases and clinical neurophysiology are introduced.
cmCourseInfo.title: Trends in Neuroscience

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores innovation in research and technology in the field of applied genetics. Specific topics vary from year to year and will be based on the course instructor's area(s) of expertise.

notes.name: Course Note

Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 20, 2019 with decisions confirmed June 28, 2019. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Molecular Cell Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: Theme-based lecture and seminar course underlining current basic science research in the area of molecular and cell biology, focusing on cell migration and its relevance to human health and disease. Topics may focus on the impact of fundamental processes underlying the cell biology, physiology and pathophysiology of cell motility in a variety of systems (e.g. immune, nervous system, cancer context).
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Molecular Cell Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and sometimes recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Individual guest lectures may not permit recordings, you will be notified in advance if this is the case. Student presentations and/or exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

courses.name: The Biology of the Human Metallome

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will discuss how heavy metals are integral to organ function through various biological pathways, the importance of metal regulation and control and its relationship with gene transcription. An introduction of metallo-therapeutics will also be featured, ranging from neurodegenerative therapies to cancer treatment.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Biology of the Human Metallome
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB265H1/BIO260H1, BIO230H1/ BIO255H1, BCH210H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Online – Asynchronous
Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need a program to play .MP4 files, such as Window Media Player and will need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on occasion.

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course, featuring a service-learning component, explores dementia. In patients with dementia, intellectual, social and occupational functioning deteriorate. The course addresses the multi-disciplinary aspects of dementia (clinical, genetic, molecular, social) with a focus on the most common cause of dementia, Alzheimer's disease.


A short application to enrol in this course is required. Information may be found via the Human Biology Program website.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dementia

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students wishing to enrol in HMB440H1 should follow the instructions found on the HMB website under Special Enrolment Courses (http://hmb.utoronto.ca/current-students/special-enrolment-courses/) Application for early consideration is due June 30 and the application for late consideration is due November 30.

Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view  asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. The placement will take place remotely.

cmCourseInfo.description: This advanced course aims to provide students with current, in-depth knowledge of the genetics of specific human diseases, including single gene (e.g., Huntington disease), multifactorial (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease), and non-Mendelian (e.g. mitochondrial DNA-related disease) disorders, and how the use of genetics to elucidate disease mechanisms can lead to treatments and personalized medicine in order to improve healthcare.
cmCourseInfo.title: Genetics of Human Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB265H1/BIO260H1, BCH210H1, HMB302H1/HMB321H1/HMB322H1/BCH311H1/CSB349H1/MGY311Y1/PSL350H1, and HMB201H1/HMB202H1/HMB203H1/HMB204H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 20, 2019 with decisions confirmed June 28, 2019. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Student presentations and/or exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Proper development of the human brain is essential for human health. This course will examine how neurodevelopment failures contribute to neurological disorders and diseases, such as epilepsy and autism. Current research from basic, translational, and clinical perspectives will be examined using case studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurodevelopmental Disorders and Diseases

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live on campus and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).  Students are strongly encouraged to participate synchronously (live stream or in-person) when possible. Students need access to Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: The bridge between basic scientific research and clinical practice integrates fundamental knowledge about molecular/cellular mechanisms and clinical disorders to increase the potential for new medical treatments, therapies and interventions as well as understanding of disease processes. Specific topics vary from year to year and will be based on the course instructor's area(s) of expertise.
cmCourseInfo.title: Personalized Medicine
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB302H1/ HMB321H1/ HMB322H1, HMB201H1/HMB202H1/HMB203H1/HMB204H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=3 Society and Its Institutions

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Exams will be synchronous (live) and delivered online during the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: The focus is on the theory and application of biostatistics and epidemiology to current developments in special topics in substantive areas of epidemiology (e.g., chronic disease, environmental & occupational health, infectious disease, methods, social, etc.).
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Epidemiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed (if the instructor/guest speaker chooses to do a in-person lecture) and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and student seminars are delivered per the meeting schedule either a in-person seminars or as an asynchronous seminar. Students need Blackboard Collaborate as part of Quercus and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course considers the health benefits and risks of different forms of exercise, with a goal of understanding how people should exercise, and how much, depending on their athletic and health goals. It introduces elements of exercise science including the biomechanics of tissues and injuries to develop an understanding of how both the quantity and quality of movement and loading contribute to healthy training and/or injury. Some common injuries in sport such as knee injuries and concussions are used as examples of how various patterns of loading can cause injuries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exercise and Sports Medicine

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

This course is online and will use a mix of asynchronous delivery (online content, practice activities, recorded videos) and synchronous according to the class schedule (once weekly online lecture webinar 1.5 hours) and office hour for Q&A 1 hour (to be scheduled). All the synchronous (live) sessions will be recorded for asynchronous viewing. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Enhancing performance has broad appeal. This course explores current developments for achieving peak performance academically, physically and emotionally. We focus on the scientific basis of the links between performance and stress, and of the benefits and risks of pharmacological methods to achieve performance enhancement. Various stress management skills are introduced.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performance Enhancement

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).  Students are strongly encouraged to participate synchronously (either in person or live steam) as numerous activities are planned (though none for grades).  Students need access to Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examine the physiological and biochemical responses of the human body to both acute and chronic bouts of physical activity. The impact of activity on health, and health on physical activity, is explored by examining adaptations from the cellular to the systemic level of bodily function.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exercise Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and tutorials are delivered per the meeting schedule. Students need (Bb Collaborate) and the ability to use (Bb Collaborate).

cmCourseInfo.description: Dentistry is one of the oldest branches of medicine responsible for the treatment of diseases of oral cavity. This course will introduce students to the key concepts as well as the latest research in the dental sciences, including but not limited to craniofacial structures, bone physiology, odontogenesis, pathogenesis of oral diseases, and technology in dental sciences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dental Sciences

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will be part of HMB pre-enrolment. Eligible program students will receive via email a ballot to rank eligible 400-level courses in order of preference between May 15 and June 21, 2020 with decisions confirmed June 30, 2020. Students who are not pre-enrolled in the course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to waitlist for the course once course enrolment starts.

Delivery Instructions

Online – Synchronous

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Student presentations will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use BB Collaborate and/or Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building on their experience in 3rd-year labs, students participate in inquiry-based laboratory experiments in diverse areas of current human biology research. Open to students in any Human Biology program. Labs start in the first week of term. (Lab Materials Fee: $105)
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Laboratory in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB310H1/ HMB311H1/ HMB312H1/ HMB314H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students wishing to enrol in HMB489H1 should follow the instructions found on the HMB website under Special Enrolment Courses (http://hmb.utoronto.ca/current-students/special-enrolment-courses/). Application due June 30, applications to be accepted on a rolling basis after until course is full.

Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture will also be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An experiential learning course exploring health-related challenges and social determinants of health in partnership with local community organizations. Lectures and tutorials will support learning of selected biological and social aspects of health and disease, neuroscience, genetics or population health, and the development of scientific knowledge translation skills relevant to the community agencies. Cannot be taken concurrently with a full year research project course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health in Community

breadthTypes.description: BR=3 Society and Its Institutions
BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students wishing to enrol in HMB490Y1 should follow the instructions found on the HMB website under Special Enrolment Courses (http://hmb.utoronto.ca/current-students/special-enrolment-courses/) Application for early consideration is due June 30 and the application for late consideration is due August 30.

Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery Hyflex:

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).  Students are strongly encouraged to participate synchronously (either in person or live steam) as numerous activities are planned (though none for grades).  Students need access to Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description:
A research project course for students enrolled in a Human Biology program, supervised by a faculty member appointed in a faculty or division at St. George Campus (Faculties of Arts & Science, Medicine, Engineering, Dalla Lana School of Public Health, etc.). Open to third and fourth year students.


Students are responsible for securing their own supervisor. Should a HMB Specialist require help securing a supervisor, the request must be made by email to the Human Biology Program Office no later than July 20 for Academic year projects and January 30 for Summer projects.


Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website.


Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Human Biology Program; please refer to the Human Biology Program website for more details
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students are not permitted to do a HMB research project concurrently with another research project
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: 0.5 FCE or more in any statistics course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website: http://hmb.utoronto.ca/current-students/special-enrolment-courses/. Students are responsible for securing their own supervisor. Should an HMB Specialist require help securing a supervisor, the request must be made by email to the Human Biology Program Office no later than July 20 for Academic year projects and January 30 for Summer projects.

Delivery Instructions

Dual Delivery Hyflex:

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components). In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives. Workshops are held over the F and S terms for students, and will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).

Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website.


Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components). In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives. Workshops are held over the F and S terms for students, and will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).
